items.text: I go out of my way to make other people feel comfortable and welcome.
items.rationale: Warmth, concern for others' comfort, and prosocial behavior are core facets of Agreeableness.

items.text: When someone disagrees with me, I try to find common ground rather than argue my point.
items.rationale: Compliance and conflict avoidance through compromise are hallmark behaviors of high Agreeableness.

items.text: People describe me as someone who is genuinely kind and considerate.
items.rationale: Third-person description of tender-mindedness and altruism, core Agreeableness facets.

items.text: I tend to trust people's intentions, even when I don't know them well.
items.rationale: Trust is a primary facet of Agreeableness in the NEO-PI-R framework.

items.text: I would rather cooperate than compete with the people around me.
items.rationale: Preference for cooperation over competition directly taps the compliance and altruism facets of Agreeableness.

items.text: If a friend needs help, I drop what I'm doing without hesitation.
items.rationale: Self-sacrificing altruism and prioritizing others' needs are central to high Agreeableness.

items.text: I find it very difficult to say no when someone asks me for a favor.
items.rationale: Difficulty refusing requests reflects the compliance and tender-mindedness facets of Agreeableness.

items.text: I believe most people are fundamentally good at heart.
items.rationale: A trusting, positive view of human nature is a defining characteristic of high Agreeableness.

items.text: She always gives people the benefit of the doubt, even when others are skeptical.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of trust and straightforwardness, core Agreeableness facets.

items.text: I feel genuinely happy when good things happen to other people.
items.rationale: Sympathetic joy and lack of envy reflect the tender-mindedness and altruism facets of Agreeableness.

items.text: I try to be polite and respectful in every interaction, even with people who frustrate me.
items.rationale: Maintaining politeness under provocation reflects compliance and modesty facets of Agreeableness.

items.text: I often put other people's needs ahead of my own, sometimes to my own detriment.
items.rationale: Self-sacrificing behavior that may be excessive is a strong marker of very high Agreeableness.

items.text: I feel uncomfortable when I see someone being treated unfairly, and I usually speak up.
items.rationale: While empathy for the mistreated is Agreeableness, speaking up assertively could also reflect low Agreeableness or Extraversion.

items.text: I tend to forgive people quickly, even when they've really hurt me.
items.rationale: Forgiveness maps to Agreeableness but could also reflect emotional regulation aspects of low Neuroticism.

items.text: I enjoy taking care of others and making sure everyone around me is doing well.
items.rationale: Caregiving maps to Agreeableness but the enjoyment and social engagement aspect could also reflect Extraversion's warmth facet.

items.text: I keep a detailed to-do list and feel satisfied when I check items off.
items.rationale: Systematic planning and task completion are core behavioral markers of the order and achievement-striving facets of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I am known for being reliable — if I say I'll do something, I always follow through.
items.rationale: Dependability and dutifulness are primary facets of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I like to have a clear plan before starting any project or task.
items.rationale: Preference for planning and deliberation are hallmark features of high Conscientiousness.

items.text: My workspace is always neat and organized — clutter really bothers me.
items.rationale: Orderliness and preference for tidiness directly tap the order facet of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I set high standards for myself and work hard to meet them.
items.rationale: Achievement striving and self-discipline are core Conscientiousness facets.

items.text: He never misses a deadline and always submits work that is thorough and polished.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of competence, dutifulness, and achievement striving — all Conscientiousness facets.

items.text: I double-check my work carefully before submitting it, even when I'm confident it's correct.
items.rationale: Thoroughness and deliberation are strong indicators of high Conscientiousness.

items.text: I find it easy to resist temptations and stay focused on long-term goals.
items.rationale: Self-discipline and impulse control in service of goals are defining features of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I feel guilty when I procrastinate or waste time on unproductive activities.
items.rationale: Guilt over unproductivity reflects the dutifulness and achievement-striving facets of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I prefer to finish one task completely before moving on to the next.
items.rationale: Sequential task completion and methodical work style are behavioral markers of high Conscientiousness.

items.text: I always arrive early or on time — being late feels disrespectful to me.
items.rationale: Punctuality and the moral framing of timeliness reflect dutifulness and order facets of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I carefully weigh the pros and cons before making any important decision.
items.rationale: Deliberation is a specific facet of Conscientiousness in the NEO-PI-R model.

items.text: I sometimes spend so long perfecting details that I lose sight of the bigger picture.
items.rationale: Perfectionism maps to Conscientiousness but excessive rumination over details could also reflect Neuroticism.

items.text: I feel anxious when things around me are disorganized or chaotic.
items.rationale: Need for order maps to Conscientiousness, but the anxiety response could also reflect Neuroticism.

items.text: I push myself to achieve ambitious goals, and I thrive on the recognition that comes with success.
items.rationale: Achievement striving is a Conscientiousness facet, but the desire for recognition and thriving on it could reflect Extraversion's assertiveness facet.

items.text: I love being around people — social gatherings energize me rather than drain me.
items.rationale: Gaining energy from social interaction is the prototypical description of high Extraversion.

items.text: I'm usually the one who starts conversations with strangers.
items.rationale: Social initiative and gregariousness are core behavioral markers of Extraversion.

items.text: People often describe me as the life of the party.
items.rationale: Classic third-person description of high Extraversion, tapping gregariousness and positive emotions facets.

items.text: I feel restless and bored when I spend too much time alone.
items.rationale: Need for external stimulation and discomfort with solitude are hallmarks of high Extraversion.

items.text: I speak up confidently in group settings and don't mind being the center of attention.
items.rationale: Assertiveness and comfort with social attention are primary facets of Extraversion.

items.text: I have a wide circle of friends and acquaintances from many different areas of my life.
items.rationale: Maintaining a large, diverse social network reflects the gregariousness facet of Extraversion.

items.text: She walks into a room and immediately starts chatting with everyone, radiating enthusiasm.
items.rationale: Third-person behavioral observation of gregariousness, warmth, and positive emotions — all Extraversion facets.

items.text: I tend to act on excitement in the moment rather than holding back.
items.rationale: Excitement seeking and spontaneous action are facets of Extraversion.

items.text: I naturally take charge in group situations and enjoy leading others.
items.rationale: Assertiveness and dominance in social settings are core facets of Extraversion.

items.text: I experience a lot of positive emotions — I laugh easily and often feel enthusiastic about life.
items.rationale: Positive emotionality is a defining facet of Extraversion in the Big Five model.

items.text: I prefer fast-paced environments where there's always something happening.
items.rationale: Preference for high levels of stimulation and activity reflects the excitement-seeking and activity facets of Extraversion.

items.text: I find it easy to express my feelings and opinions to others.
items.rationale: Emotional expressiveness and social assertiveness are behavioral indicators of high Extraversion.

items.text: I enjoy meeting new people, though I also care deeply about making a genuine connection with them.
items.rationale: Meeting new people is Extraversion, but the emphasis on genuine connection could also reflect Agreeableness.

items.text: I get a rush from trying thrilling activities like skydiving or bungee jumping.
items.rationale: Excitement seeking is an Extraversion facet, but sensation seeking also overlaps with low Conscientiousness and Openness to experience.

items.text: I love brainstorming with a group — bouncing ideas off other people sparks my creativity.
items.rationale: Social brainstorming reflects Extraversion's gregariousness, but the creativity and idea generation component could map to Openness.

items.text: I worry about things that most people seem to handle without stress.
items.rationale: Excessive worry relative to others is a core marker of the anxiety facet of Neuroticism.

items.text: My mood can shift dramatically from one hour to the next without any obvious reason.
items.rationale: Emotional lability and unpredictable mood shifts are hallmarks of high Neuroticism.

items.text: I often replay embarrassing moments in my head long after they've happened.
items.rationale: Rumination and self-conscious distress are core features of the self-consciousness facet of Neuroticism.

items.text: I feel overwhelmed by stress more easily than most people I know.
items.rationale: Low stress tolerance and vulnerability to being overwhelmed are defining features of the vulnerability facet of Neuroticism.

items.text: Small setbacks can ruin my entire day and leave me feeling defeated.
items.rationale: Disproportionate emotional reactions to minor stressors reflect the depression and vulnerability facets of Neuroticism.

items.text: He tends to catastrophize — if one thing goes wrong, he assumes everything will fall apart.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of catastrophic thinking, a cognitive pattern strongly associated with high Neuroticism.

items.text: I frequently feel tense and on edge, even when there's no clear reason to be anxious.
items.rationale: Free-floating anxiety and chronic tension are prototypical markers of the anxiety facet of Neuroticism.

items.text: I am easily hurt by criticism, even when it's meant to be constructive.
items.rationale: Sensitivity to criticism and emotional reactivity to negative feedback reflect the self-consciousness and vulnerability facets of Neuroticism.

items.text: I often feel sad or down without being able to pinpoint exactly why.
items.rationale: Unexplained sadness and depressive affect are core features of the depression facet of Neuroticism.

items.text: I have trouble falling asleep because my mind races with worries and what-ifs.
items.rationale: Worry-driven insomnia is a behavioral consequence of the anxiety facet of Neuroticism.

items.text: I get irritated quickly and sometimes snap at people before I can stop myself.
items.rationale: Irritability and poor anger regulation reflect the angry hostility facet of Neuroticism.

items.text: I tend to dwell on my mistakes and have a hard time letting go of regret.
items.rationale: Rumination and persistent regret are cognitive-emotional patterns central to high Neuroticism.

items.text: When I'm under pressure, I sometimes feel like I just can't cope.
items.rationale: Feeling unable to cope under pressure maps to Neuroticism's vulnerability facet, though it could also reflect situational factors or low self-efficacy related to Conscientiousness.

items.text: I second-guess my decisions constantly and rarely feel confident that I made the right choice.
items.rationale: Chronic indecisiveness maps to Neuroticism's self-consciousness and anxiety, but could also reflect the deliberation facet of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I sometimes eat or drink more than I should when I'm feeling stressed or upset.
items.rationale: Stress-driven overconsumption reflects the impulsiveness facet of Neuroticism, but impulsive behavior also maps to low Conscientiousness (self-discipline).

items.text: I am fascinated by philosophical questions about the nature of reality and existence.
items.rationale: Intellectual curiosity about abstract philosophical topics is a core marker of the ideas facet of Openness.

items.text: I actively seek out art, music, and literature that challenges my perspective.
items.rationale: Seeking aesthetically and intellectually challenging experiences reflects the aesthetics and ideas facets of Openness.

items.text: I have a vivid imagination and often get lost in elaborate daydreams.
items.rationale: Vivid imagination and rich fantasy life are defining features of the fantasy facet of Openness.

items.text: I enjoy exploring unfamiliar cultures, cuisines, and ways of life.
items.rationale: Curiosity about diverse cultural experiences reflects the actions and values facets of Openness.

items.text: I find beauty in things that other people often overlook — a pattern of light, an unusual sound.
items.rationale: Heightened aesthetic sensitivity and perceptual awareness are core features of the aesthetics facet of Openness.

items.text: I question conventional wisdom and enjoy thinking about why things are the way they are.
items.rationale: Intellectual questioning and challenging established norms reflect the ideas and values facets of Openness.

items.text: He is always reading about some new topic — last month it was astrophysics, this month it's medieval history.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of broad intellectual curiosity and voracious learning, hallmarks of the ideas facet of Openness.

items.text: I feel deeply moved by music, poetry, or visual art in a way that's hard to put into words.
items.rationale: Deep emotional responsiveness to aesthetic stimuli is a primary marker of the aesthetics facet of Openness.

items.text: I prefer variety and novelty over routine and predictability in my daily life.
items.rationale: Preference for novelty over routine reflects the actions facet of Openness.

items.text: I often think about how things could be different — alternative histories, hypothetical scenarios, future possibilities.
items.rationale: Counterfactual and hypothetical thinking reflects the fantasy and ideas facets of Openness.

items.text: I believe that exposure to different viewpoints and value systems makes a person wiser.
items.rationale: Valuing diverse perspectives and intellectual pluralism reflects the values facet of Openness.

items.text: I enjoy experimenting with creative projects, even if the results are imperfect or unconventional.
items.rationale: Willingness to experiment creatively without concern for convention reflects the aesthetics and actions facets of Openness.

items.text: I pay close attention to my inner emotional life and try to understand what I'm feeling and why.
items.rationale: Openness to feelings is a specific facet of Openness, but introspection about emotions could also relate to Neuroticism's emotional awareness.

items.text: I tend to challenge authority and question rules that don't seem to have a good reason behind them.
items.rationale: Questioning authority maps to the values facet of Openness, but could also reflect low Agreeableness (antagonism toward authority).

items.text: I like to keep my options open rather than commit to a rigid plan.
items.rationale: Preference for flexibility could reflect Openness to experience (actions facet) or low Conscientiousness (lack of deliberation and planning).
